security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and example code snippets. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond normal AI tool behavior. The SKILL.md file defines visualization capabilities for the AI to use when responding to user requests.

content.value_statement: Users need to communicate data insights through visual formats but lack the expertise to select the right chart type or library. This skill provides AI-driven guidance to generate clear, professional visualizations using matplotlib, seaborn, plotly, and altair.
actual_capabilities: Create line charts, bar charts, pie charts, scatter plots, histograms, box plots, and heatmaps
Generate visualizations using matplotlib, seaborn, plotly, and altair libraries
Build multi-axis plots and subplot grids for complex data
Apply custom themes, styling, annotations, and labels to visualizations
Export charts to PNG, SVG, and PDF formats
limitations: Cannot access external datasets without explicit user-provided data
Visualizations are generated as code that users must run locally
Does not provide real-time or streaming data visualization
Limited to static code generation without interactive dashboard creation

use_cases.title: Statistical visualization
use_cases.description: Generate statistical charts and plots for data analysis reports and presentations using seaborn and matplotlib.

use_cases.title: Code generation for charts
use_cases.description: Produce Python visualization code for integration into applications, notebooks, and data pipelines.

use_cases.title: Research data presentation
use_cases.description: Create clear, publication-ready figures for academic papers and research documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Basic line chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a line chart using matplotlib showing trends over time. Include title, axis labels, and legend if needed.

prompt_templates.title: Statistical distribution
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a histogram with KDE overlay using seaborn to show the distribution of a numerical dataset. Add appropriate labels and styling.

prompt_templates.title: Interactive visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Build an interactive scatter plot using plotly with hover tooltips, zoom, and pan capabilities for exploring relationships between variables.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-panel dashboard
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a figure with multiple subplots showing correlation heatmap, distribution plots, and time series on separate axes with shared styling.

best_practices: Select chart types that match your data structure and the insight you want to highlight
Include clear titles, axis labels, and legends to make visualizations self-explanatory
Use color schemes that are accessible and appropriate for your audience
anti_patterns: Using 3D charts for simple comparisons, which distorts data perception
Overloading visualizations with too many data series or colors
Forgetting to label axes or include units of measurement

faq.question: Which visualization library should I choose?
faq.answer: Use matplotlib for static charts, seaborn for statistical plots, plotly for interactive web charts, and altair for declarative visualizations.

faq.question: What image formats are supported for export?
faq.answer: Common formats include PNG for images, SVG for scalable graphics, and PDF for publication-quality documents.

faq.question: Can this skill connect to databases?
faq.answer: No. You must provide the data as input. The skill generates code that processes data you specify.

faq.question: Is my data stored or shared?
faq.answer: No. Data remains local. The skill only generates visualization code that runs in your environment.

faq.question: Why is the output just code?
faq.answer: The skill generates Python code that you run locally. This ensures you have full control over execution and dependencies.

faq.question: How does this compare to BI tools like Tableau?
faq.answer: This skill generates customizable code for programmatic visualization. BI tools offer drag-and-drop interfaces but require separate installation.
